title: Holiness and Judgment
shortSummary: Leviticus 20 outlines God's commands for holiness among the Israelites, emphasizing strict prohibitions against idolatry, sexual immorality, and occult practices. The chapter highlights the severe consequences for disobedience and calls God's people to live distinct, sanctified lives as His holy nation.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The mediator through whom the LORD delivers His commands to the children of Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen people who are called to obey His statutes and maintain holiness.

keyCharacters.name: Strangers that sojourn in Israel
keyCharacters.description: Non-Israelites living among the Israelites who are also subject to God's laws.

keyCharacters.name: Molech
keyCharacters.description: A pagan deity to whom child sacrifice was offered, strictly forbidden by God.

definitions.definition: A Canaanite god associated with child sacrifice, whose worship was detestable to God.
Spirits or entities consulted through necromancy or witchcraft, forbidden as occult practices.
To set apart as holy, dedicated to God’s service and moral purity.
Idolatry or spiritual unfaithfulness, often used metaphorically for sexual immorality.

outline.heading: Prohibition of Child Sacrifice to Molech
outline.description: God commands the death penalty for anyone offering their children to Molech, emphasizing the defilement of His sanctuary and the necessity of communal responsibility to uphold holiness.

outline.heading: Condemnation of Occult Practices
outline.description: Those who consult familiar spirits or wizards are to be cut off, highlighting the incompatibility of occultism with the holiness God requires.

outline.heading: Laws Against Sexual Immorality
outline.description: A detailed list of forbidden sexual relations is given, with severe penalties including death, underscoring the importance of purity and the sanctity of family relationships.

outline.heading: Call to Obedience and Separation
outline.description: God commands Israel to keep His statutes to avoid being rejected by the land, to avoid pagan practices, and to live as a holy, distinct people set apart for Him.

application: Commit to personal holiness by avoiding practices and behaviors that defile your relationship with God.
Reject occult and idolatrous influences, trusting solely in God’s power and guidance.
Honor and respect family relationships as God’s design for order and purity.
Obey God’s commands fully to experience His blessing and protection in your life.

keyVerses.text: Sanctify yourselves therefore, and be ye holy: for I am the LORD your God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates the chapter’s central call for God’s people to live holy lives reflecting His character.

keyVerses.text: And the man that committeth adultery with another man's wife, even he that committeth adultery with his neighbour's wife, the adulterer and the adulteress shall surely be put to death.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the seriousness with which God views sexual sin and the protection of marriage.

keyVerses.text: And ye shall be holy unto me: for I the LORD am holy, and have severed you from other people, that ye should be mine.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s purpose in calling Israel to holiness: to be His treasured possession, distinct from the nations.
